Award.AwardTitle: Feedback Control of Highly Dynamic Spatial Locomotion in 3D Bipedal Robots

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project contributes to the foundations of feedback control through the study of highly dynamic motions for 3D bipedal robots.
Intellectual Merit: It is estimated that 70% of the earth's landmass is inaccessible to wheeled or tracked vehicles. This has stimulated interest in the design of robots that use legs as a means of locomotion. With legs, robots can step over obstacles or use sparse footholds (as in ladders). The research conducted under this NSF grant is enhancing the ability to design robots that can function in a wide range of natural environments. In particular, this work focuses on developing feedback control algorithms that will allow bipedal robots to walk, run, and turn rapidly, without stumbling and falling, thereby bringing closer the day when such robots can assist humans, and eventually stand in for them, in situations of extreme danger, such as when responding to a major industrial accident or a fire in a home.
Broader Impacts: The research being conducted in this grant is enhancing the interest in STEM subjects, by giving tours of the 3D robotics laboratory to hundreds of students, from grade school through high school. More broadly, the work is being highlighted in the media, informing the public about the excitement of cutting-edge engineering research and how it benefits society.
Dissemination: The research conducted in this grant is being published in leading peer-reviewed journals and conferences. The work is also available on public web sites and a YouTube channel, Dynamic Leg Locomotion. Videos from this channel have been featured worldwide on numerous television programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Feedback Control of Highly Dynamic Spatial Locomotion in 3D Bipedal Robots

If you have watched a video of bipedal (i.e. two-legged) robot walking far slower than people normally walk, you might have asked yourself why? Is it because the robots are too clunky, their motors are too weak, or their limbs are too heavy? While that might be a part of the answer, it is not the main reason that robots these days walk as slow as they do. For the most part, they walk slowly because their limbs are controlled by algorithms (i.e., the mathematical and software equivalents of your brain and nervous system) that have been poorly designed. This grant project invented, analyzed, and tested algorithms to make robots walk at the speed of life. You can find our work by searching on MARLO ROBOT. We have many YouTube videos that demonstrate our work. Once you find the videos, you will easily find preprints of all our papers by clicking on the link that takes you to my website from our YouTube channel.

By the way, when I say “we” and “our”, I am referring to my team, which consists of PhD students who trained under the sponsorship of this grant to learn about robotics, as well as research I have done myself working on this project. One of the students who worked on this project is now in industry, helping to develop high performance driver assist systems that makes “normal cars” safer.  These systems have a lot of automation, similar to a robot! Another of the students is preparing to pursue an academic career.

Speaking a bit more technically, we developed a means to optimally adjust the parameters in our robot control algorithms so that the robot would not be easily tripped up when walking over undulating or uneven terrain. Because we build-in this robustness to terrain uncertainty, we can permit the robot to walk much more quickly and be confident that it is unlikely to fall.

Another thing we invented were some applied mathematics that tied Lagrange’s equations to a branch of geometric control theory. This mathematics helped us to design walking algorithms that would perform well over a wide range of walking speeds. This also enhanced the agility of our robot, MARLO.

Importantly, we tested all of this thoroughly on our robot and then published all of the work in the scientific literature, making sure that a free copy is always available on our website.

One measure of our success is that others are adopting our work. We are especially proud to see our methods being used in prosthetic lower limbs in the work of Professors Robert Gregg (UT Dallas) and Aaron Ames (Ga Tech).
